Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Collaborative Research: Diagnostics and Prognostics Using Temporal Causal Models for Cyber Physical Systems- A Case of Smart Electric Grid

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Reliable operation of cyber-physical systems (CPS) of societal importance such as Smart Electric Grids is critical for the seamless functioning of a vibrant economy. Sustained power outages can lead to major disruptions over large areas costing millions of dollars. Efficient computational techniques and tools that curtail such systematic failures by performing fault diagnosis and prognostics are therefore necessary. The Smart Electric Grid is a CPS: it consists of networks of physical components (including generation, transmission, and distribution facilities) interfaced with cyber components (such as intelligent sensors, communication networks, and control software). This grant provides funding to develop new methods to build models for the smart grid representing the failure dependencies in the physical and cyber components. The models will be used to build an integrated system-wide solution for diagnosing faults and predicting future failure propagations that can account for existing protection mechanisms. The original contribution of this work will be in the integrated modeling of failures on multiple levels in a large distributed cyber-physical system and the development of novel, hierarchical, robust, online algorithms for diagnostics and prognostics.

If successful, the model-based fault diagnostics and prognostics techniques will improve the effectiveness of isolating failures in large systems by identifying impending failure propagations and determining the time to critical failures that will increase system reliability and reduce the losses accrued due to failures. This work will bridge the gap between fault management approaches used in computer science and power engineering that are needed as the grid becomes smarter, more complex, and more data intensive. Outcomes of this project will include modeling and run-time software prototypes, research publications, and experimental results in collaborations with industry partners that will be made available to the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has studied how the resilience of the power grid can be improved, using modeling techniques and algorithms developed for cyber-physical systems. The power grid is a good example for a cyber-physical system, as it incorporates both a physical system (containing generators, transmission and distribution lines, transformers, customer loads) and a cyber system (the myriads of networked embedded computers that control and protect the system). In particular, we looked at situations where a physical fault (e.g. a high-voltage line shorted to the ground) is compounded by a cyber fault (e.g. the control software mistakenly not actuating a circuit breaker). We developed techniques to model such systems, including the modeling of the faults in the cyber system. Next, we have developed techniques to diagnose such problems where both physical and cyber faults are present. The goal of the diagnosis was to quickly find out what went wrong and what components (power lines, transformers, circuit breakers, etc.) have failed. The models used in the diagnosis were automatically computed from the circuit diagram of the power network. Next, we have developed an algorithm that can predict what will happen in the case of such double faults. This is critical, as double faults can often lead to cascade effects that bring down large sections of the grid. The algorithm could be used off-line to compute a 'cascade map' which then can be used by the operators (or an automated system) at operation time to quickly predict and warn about an impending cascade. Finally, we have developed an optimization algorithm that reduces power-consuming loads in order to protect the network. Such calculations can be done at design time, and the calculated load shedding procedures can be stored in an automation system to prepare for an emergency.

In summary, we have developed a modeling approach for automatically generating models for the online, real-time diagnosis of the power grid (transmission systems), an algorithm for diagnosing simultaneous failures in the physical and the cyber parts of the power system, an algorithm to predict the potential failure cascades, and an algorithm for load shedding in order the prevent fault cascades from developing. The algorithms and tools have been tried and evaluated on realistic examples from industrial practice (e.g. IEEE bus system examples).
